LIMPS

ithium,

ron,

etals,

ackers/stuffer,

ustained release drugs (especially beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers)
Lithium overdose

Iron
Heavy metals
Toxic ingestions of sustained- or delayed-release formulations
Drugs carried by body packers
Additional considerations:
Agents that cause
bezoar
or concretion formation
Paint chips containing
lead
Be mindful that the addition of PEG to activated charcoal significantly decreases activated charcoal's adsorptive capacity

Contraindications.text:
Preceding
diarrhea
Ingestion of substances expected to result in significant diarrhea (except
heavy metals
)
Bowel obstruction
(as evidenced by lack of bowel sounds)
avoid chilled solutions in neonates given risk for hypothermia

Procedure.text:
Give polyethylene glycol via NGT or PO (if tolerates) until rectal effluent is clear
Adult: 1.5-2 L/hr
Peds 6-12yr: 1 L/hr
Peds <6yr: 0.5 L/hr
Peds alt: 20-40 mL/kg/hr in young children
Give
ondansetron
or
metoclopramide
as needed for
nausea/vomiting

Complications.text:
Bloating
Cramping
Rectal irritation (from frequent bowel movements)
